sub_subject.name: Economics (Micro, Macro & Biblical Stewardship)
sub_subject.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Economics (Micro, Macro & Biblical Stewardship) (History & Social Studies)

objectives.objective_text: Identify sharing as kindness.
Name the widow who gave two coins.
Identify opportunities to give.
Identify fairness.
Name stealing and cheating as wrong.
Identify Usury (charging unfair interest).
Identify 'mine' and 'yours'.
Name stealing as taking what isn't yours.
Identify the story of Naboth's Vineyard.
Identify that money is a tool.
Name God as the owner of everything.
Identify the responsibility to use money well.
Identify work as good.
Name God as a worker (Creator).
Identify laziness as a sin.
Identify rich countries and poor countries.
Name clean water and schools as things everyone needs.
Identify the Human Development Index (HDI).
Identify money from other countries (Euro, Yen, Peso).
Name the Dollar.
Identify the Euro.
Identify the internet connecting everyone.
Name famous brands found everywhere (Coke, Nike).
Identify Multinational Corporations.
Identify labels that say 'Made in China' or 'Made in Mexico'.
Name ships that carry boxes across the ocean.
Identify a Trade Deficit.
Identify that Jesus loves the poor.
Name giving food and clothes as helping.
Identify Christian relief organizations.
Identify good times and hard times.
Name the Great Depression.
Identify signs of a growing economy.
Identify sharing rules vs. trading rules.
Name the government as a rule-maker.
Identify a 'Mixed Economy' (most countries).
Identify taxes as money we give the government.
Name roads and schools as things taxes pay for.
Identify the National Debt.
Identify that candy costs more now than before.
Name money losing its value.
Identify Hyperinflation.
Identify a rich country vs. a poor country.
Name jobs as how people earn money.
Identify the 'Standard of Living'.
Identify the bank where money is kept.
Name the 'Fed' as the bank for banks.
Identify the Central Bank.
Identify things we need no matter what (medicine).
Name things we only buy if they are cheap (candy).
Identify how sales work (low price = high sales).
Identify a business (store or factory).
Name 'Profit' as money kept after paying bills.
Identify the goal of a business (to make a profit).
Identify that choosing one thing means losing another.
Name the choice I didn't pick.
Identify that we can't have everything we want.
Name a 'Need' (food) vs. a 'Want' (toy).
Identify 'Opportunity Cost' (what you give up to get something).
Identify jobs people do (baker, builder).
Name trading lunch items.
Identify imports (goods coming in) and exports (goods going out).
Identify that stores sell what people want.
Name a price tag.
Identify the 'Market Price'.
Recall that God loves a cheerful giver.
Observe that giving makes us happy.
Recall that we should pay what we owe.
Observe that God cares about fair rules.
Recall 'Thou shalt not steal'.
Observe that we share because we want to, not because we have to.
Recall that we are managers (stewards).
Observe that money can't buy happiness.
Recall that Adam had a job in the garden.
Observe that we work for Jesus.
Recall that we should help poor neighbors.
Observe pictures of life in developing nations.
Recall that you have to change money when you travel.
Observe that different money looks different.
Recall that the world feels smaller.
Observe that we can talk to anyone instantly.
Recall that we buy things from other countries.
Observe bananas in the grocery store (they don't grow here).
Recall that we should share.
Observe that not everyone has a home.
Recall that sometimes people lose jobs.
Observe that businesses open and close.
Recall that in some places, the king owns everything.
Observe that in America, people own businesses.
Recall that the government spends money.
Observe that we pay tax at the store.
Recall a story about wheelbarrows of money (Germany).
Observe prices going up.
Recall that it is good when people have work.
Observe that prices change over time.
Recall that interest is money paid for borrowing.
Observe coins and bills.
Recall that some prices change a lot.
Observe that people buy less when prices go up.
Recall that businesses make things to sell.
Observe that workers get paid.
Recall that we can't be in two places at once.
Observe that time is like money.
Recall that we have to make choices.
Observe that money runs out if we spend it all.
Recall that we can't make everything ourselves.
Observe that we help each other by doing different jobs.
Recall that rare things cost more.
Observe that if everyone wants a toy, the price goes up.
Summarize the concept of the Tithe.
Explain the difference between stingy and generous.
Explain the danger of hoarding.
Defend generosity as an antidote to materialism.
Summarize the command to use honest scales.
Explain why we should pay workers on time.
Explain the biblical view of debt.
Defend the rights of the laborer and the employer.
Summarize the 8th and 10th Commandments (Stealing/Coveting).
Explain that the Bible protects private property.
Explain the failure of Ananias and Sapphira (lying, not owning).
Defend the moral legitimacy of ownership.
Summarize the warning 'The love of money is a root of all kinds of evil'.
Explain that being rich is not a sin, but it is dangerous.
Explain the spiritual discipline of simplicity.
Defend the moral neutrality of money itself.
Summarize Colossians 3:23 (Work heartily as for the Lord).
Explain that all honest work pleases God.
Explain the dignity of manual labor.
Defend work as a pre-fall blessing, not a curse.
Summarize the difference between Developed and Developing nations.
Explain what 'Infrastructure' is (roads, power, internet).
Explain the role of Microfinance.
Defend the role of property rights in development.
Summarize what an Exchange Rate is.
Explain why the dollar gets stronger or weaker.
Explain Hyperinflation in history (Zimbabwe, Venezuela).
Defend the stability provided by the dollar standard.
Summarize what Globalization is.
Explain the Global Supply Chain (parts from everywhere).
Explain the backlash against globalization.
Defend the cultural benefits of exchange.
Summarize Imports and Exports.
Explain why we trade (we have what they need, they have what we need).
Explain the World Trade Organization (WTO).
Defend the moral case for trade (lifting nations out of poverty).
Summarize the biblical command to care for the widow and orphan.
Explain the difference between relief (emergency) and development (long term).
Explain the role of the local church in relief.
Defend the dignity of the poor (Imago Dei).
Summarize the Boom and Bust cycle.
Explain a Recession (economy shrinks).
Explain 'Creative Destruction'.
Defend the resilience of the market economy.
Summarize the Free Market (people decide).
Explain the Command Economy (government decides).
Explain the role of incentives in different systems.
Defend the moral superiority of voluntary exchange.
Summarize where tax money goes (Military, Roads, Schools).
Explain the difference between a Deficit (yearly) and Debt (total).
Explain the Laffer Curve (tax rates vs. revenue).
Defend a biblical view of taxation and limited government.
Summarize Inflation (money buys less).
Explain why printing too much money is bad.
Explain the 'Wage-Price Spiral'.
Defend sound money principles.
Summarize what GDP is (all the money a country makes).
Explain what 'Unemployment' means.
Explain the limitations of GDP (doesn't measure happiness or volunteer work).
Defend the use of Real GDP vs. Nominal GDP.
Summarize what the Federal Reserve does.
Explain Interest Rates (the price of money).
Explain Fractional Reserve Banking.
Defend or critique the fiat money system.
Summarize why we buy less soda if it costs $10.
Explain that we still buy water even if it costs more.
Explain why gas prices fluctuate.
Defend the pricing strategy of a business based on elasticity.
Summarize what an Entrepreneur does.
Explain the difference between Revenue (sales) and Profit.
Explain the role of profit as a signal.
Defend the social utility of profit-making firms.
Summarize the definition: The value of the next best alternative.
Explain opportunity cost in time (homework vs. playing).
Explain why 'free' things still have a cost.
Defend the importance of considering unseen costs (Bastiat).
Summarize the problem: Unlimited wants, limited resources.
Explain why we have to trade to get things.
Explain the four factors of production (Land, Labor, Capital, Entrepreneurship).
Defend the efficiency of markets in handling scarcity.
Summarize why specialization makes work faster.
Explain the 'Division of Labor' (pin factory example).
Explain why trade creates wealth for both sides.
Defend the mutual benefit of international markets.
Summarize how prices are set (buyers and sellers agree).
Explain what happens when there is too much of something (Surplus).
Explain 'Equilibrium' (where the lines cross).
Defend the price mechanism as an information signal.
Compare biblical charity with government taxes.
Analyze Paul's instructions on giving in 2 Corinthians 8-9.
Interpret 'It is more blessed to give than to receive'.
Connect generosity to trust in God's provision.
Compare fair trade with exploitation.
Analyze the OT laws protecting the poor (Gleaning).
Interpret James 5 (warning to rich oppressors).
Connect justice to the treatment of the vulnerable.
Compare the early church sharing (voluntary) with Communism (forced).
Analyze the distinction between Acts 2/4 and Socialism.
Interpret the right to own property as a stewardship responsibility.
Connect property rights to liberty.
Compare Solomon's wealth with his emptiness.
Analyze the Parable of the Rich Fool.
Interpret Jesus' teaching on Mammon.
Connect wealth to the obligation to help others.
Compare working for money vs. working for glory.
Analyze the Protestant Work Ethic.
Interpret the Parable of the Talents.
Connect vocation to 'Calling'.
Compare Per Capita Income.
Analyze the causes of poverty (corruption, war, lack of rule of law).
Interpret the 'Poverty Trap'.
Connect education to economic growth.
Compare a cheap currency (good for selling) with a strong one (good for buying).
Analyze how exchange rates affect tourism and trade.
Interpret a currency conversion chart.
Connect the US Dollar as the 'Reserve Currency'.
Compare local culture with global culture.
Analyze the cultural homogenization caused by globalization.
Interpret the impact of shipping containers on trade.
Connect globalization to the spread of ideas and religion.
Compare Free Trade with Protectionism (keeping jobs at home).
Analyze the concept of Absolute vs. Comparative Advantage.
Interpret the function of Tariffs and Quotas.
Connect trade wars to prices in stores.
Compare giving a fish vs. teaching to fish.
Analyze the causes of systemic poverty.
Interpret 'When Helping Hurts' (doing harm by giving wrongly).
Connect the Gospel to holistic restoration.
Compare a Depression with a Recession.
Analyze the phases: Expansion, Peak, Contraction, Trough.
Interpret the psychological factor in economic cycles.
Connect historical events to economic downturns.
Compare Capitalism with Socialism/Communism.
Analyze Adam Smith's 'Invisible Hand'.
Interpret the tragedy of central planning (shortages).
Connect private property rights to prosperity.
Compare high taxes with low taxes.
Analyze the federal budget process.
Interpret Progressive vs. Regressive taxes.
Connect government spending to economic stimulus.
Compare the price of a car in 1950 vs. today.
Analyze the causes of inflation (Demand-Pull vs. Cost-Push).
Interpret the impact of inflation on savings.
Connect deflation to the Great Depression.
Compare a recession (bad times) with growth (good times).
Analyze the components of GDP (Consumption, Investment, Government, Net Exports).
Interpret the Business Cycle (Boom and Bust).
Connect the CPI (Consumer Price Index) to the cost of living.
Compare easy money (low rates) with tight money (high rates).
Analyze how the Fed controls the money supply.
Interpret the effect of raising interest rates on inflation.
Connect the banking system to the economy.
Compare 'Needs' (Inelastic) with 'Luxuries' (Elastic).
Analyze Price Elasticity of Demand.
Interpret why taxes on cigarettes work (or don't work).
Connect elasticity to total revenue.
Compare Fixed Costs (Rent) with Variable Costs (Materials).
Analyze the Law of Diminishing Returns.
Interpret Economies of Scale (bigger is cheaper).
Connect competition to lower prices for customers.
Compare the cost of buying a bike vs. saving for a car.
Apply opportunity cost to family decisions.
Analyze the trade-offs in government spending (guns vs. butter).
Interpret the sunk cost fallacy.
Connect opportunity cost to comparative advantage.
Compare saving for later with spending now.
Analyze the concept of 'TINSTAAFL' (There Is No Such Thing As A Free Lunch).
Interpret decision-making using cost-benefit analysis.
Connect scarcity to the need for economics.
Compare making a whole shoe vs. just making the laces.
Analyze the benefits of voluntary exchange.
Interpret the concept of Comparative Advantage.
Connect specialization to interdependence.
Compare a Shortage with a Surplus.
Analyze the Law of Demand (price up, demand down).
Interpret a Supply and Demand graph.
Connect shifts in demand to changing trends.
Evaluate the 'Prosperity Gospel' view of giving.
Evaluate the ethics of the free market.
Evaluate the history of collectivism.
Evaluate the spiritual risks of affluence.
Evaluate the 'Institutions' theory of wealth (Acemoglu).
Evaluate the role of the IMF (International Monetary Fund).
Evaluate the environmental impact of global shipping.
Evaluate the impact of outsourcing on domestic labor.
Evaluate the effectiveness of government welfare vs. private charity.
Evaluate the government's role in smoothing the cycle.
Evaluate the efficiency of markets vs. state control.
Evaluate the long-term impact of national debt.
Evaluate the winners and losers of inflation (Debtors vs. Savers).
Evaluate the trade-off between unemployment and inflation (Phillips Curve).
Evaluate the independence of the Federal Reserve.
Evaluate the cross-price elasticity of substitute goods.
Evaluate different market structures (Monopoly, Oligopoly, Perfect Competition).
Evaluate the implicit costs of business decisions.
Evaluate the ethical implications of resource allocation.
Evaluate the risks of over-specialization (supply chain fragility).
Evaluate the effect of price ceilings and floors.
Construct a personal plan for stewardship.
Synthesize the use of wealth for eternal purposes.
Construct a definition of biblical justice vs. social justice.
Synthesize economic liberty with moral responsibility.
Construct a defense of private property rights.
Synthesize the relationship between property and charity.
Construct a biblical view of wealth creation vs. wealth redistribution.
Synthesize the concept of 'blessed to be a blessing'.
Construct a theology of work.
Synthesize the redemption of work in the Kingdom.
Construct a critique of Foreign Aid (effective vs. harmful).
Synthesize the biblical mandate for justice and mercy in development.
Construct an explanation of floating vs. pegged exchange rates.
Synthesize the impact of currency manipulation.
Construct an evaluation of the winners and losers of globalization.
Synthesize the future of globalization in a polarized world.
Construct an argument for the benefits of global trade.
Synthesize the tension between economic efficiency and national security.
Construct a strategy for effective poverty alleviation.
Synthesize a biblical theology of wealth and poverty.
Construct an analysis of the causes of the Business Cycle.
Synthesize Austrian vs. Keynesian business cycle theories.
Construct a critique of Marxist economic theory.
Synthesize the history of the Cold War as an economic conflict.
Construct an argument for or against Keynesian stimulus.
Synthesize the political challenges of balancing the budget.
Construct an explanation of the Quantity Theory of Money.
Synthesize the history of fiat currency vs. the gold standard.
Construct an analysis of current economic indicators.
Synthesize the impact of productivity on national wealth.
Construct a flowchart of how money is created.
Construct a graph showing elastic vs. inelastic demand curves.
Synthesize the impact of time on elasticity.
Construct a business plan including cost analysis.
Synthesize the relationship between marginal cost and marginal revenue.
Construct a decision matrix weighing opportunity costs.
Synthesize opportunity cost with spiritual stewardship.
Construct a production possibilities frontier curve.
Synthesize the relationship between scarcity and value.
Construct an argument for free trade based on efficiency.
Synthesize the impact of specialization on the standard of living.
Construct a graph showing a shift in supply due to external factors.
Synthesize the impact of elasticity on consumer behavior.
Evaluate the modern idol of 'Career'.
Synthesize the role of monetary policy in the 2008 financial crisis.
